Extrêmement déçu. Vu la hype générale visible partout, je finis par me laisser tenter malgré le frein du prix astronomique. Et....franchement, déception. Ok, la qualité du matos est exceptionnelle, d'où ma note de 3 minimum. Mais les points négatifs s'accumulent en avalanche : un livret de règle IN-DI-GES-TE. Je suis quelqu'un de patient, capable de prendre du temps dans les jeux experts complexes voire lourds; là j'ai passé deux journées à lire et relire les règles tout en regardant multiples vidéos d'explications (bravo à la chaîne JeanMichelGrosJeux d'ailleurs); mais le pire, c'est que non seulement le livret de règles est mal structuré, mal écrit, manque d'exemples et d'illustrations, mais en prime il ne suffit pas à comprendre toutes les subtilités, avec un un grand nombre de points d'explications tout simplement absents. C'est extrêmement frustrant d'accepter de s'investir lourdement en temps et en argent pour se retrouver sans savoir ce qu'il faut faire.
Autre chose, l'absence de marge progressive : le jeu est beaucoup trop lourd en subtilités et micro-points de règles très particulières qui, accumulées, rend l'avalanche d'information complètement indigeste. Et les premières parties sont plus que pénibles : on ne s'amuse pas, on se fait rouler dessus, on ne sait pas quoi faire, on n'a pas le droit à une seconde chance (malgré que le perso ne meure pas au sens propre), et on se fait dégommer dès le premier combat sans rien comprendre à ce qui nous est arrivé.
On en déduit vite qu'il faut bien une vingtaine de parties pour commencer à maîtriser suffisamment la vue d'ensemble des possibilités et enfin commencer à apprécier le jeu. Perso, je ne me suis pas amusé.
Et cette perspective ne m'amuse pas non plus.
Enfin, le style même du jeu, on aime ou on déteste : ce n'est que du combat tactique, avec un aspect narratif minimaliste assez inutile au final; le tout sur une grille hyper abstraite et calculatoire. Gloomhaven ou Heroes of Normandy, jeux de combats tactiques, sont bien plus immersifs et amusants en comparaison (et bien plus faciles d'accès), tout en étant aussi riches en possibilités tactiques.
Bref, une grande déception, et je vais donc m'en séparer très rapidement. Je ne comprends sincèrement pas la hype générale autour de ce titre.

Too Many Bones is a cooperative game focused on small-scale tactical battles and light strategic decision-making. Characters level up as the game progresses, preparing for the boss battle. Unfortunately, the leveling feels weak because the generic attributes seem better to level than the distinctive skills/dice, and the distinctive dice are generally only used once per battle and often don't roll what you want when you need it. There isn't enough storytelling since the strategic/overland part is random cards that are just deciding between different rewards with some light flavor text. Since there's no hidden information for the players or per-character motivations, multiplayer games may as well be solitaire with just one person making all the decisions. Worst of all, the battles aren't engaging and many enemies are impervious to certain actions (e.g., flying enemies that I can only attack every other turn) or that strongly discourage certain actions (e.g., an enemy that locks my attack dice if I attack it). Finally, the game is extremely expensive for no good reason. Yes, neoprene mats and weighted poker chips are a luxury, but Quarriors provides more fun and so many dice for less than half the price. I really wanted to like this, but it isn't worth the time or money.

Only played this twice solo, but first impressions where not good. Maybe Patches is not the best Gearloc for playing solo, but I scarcely had an exciting and satisfying battle. The encounters were completely unrelated and the writing was bad. The baddie point system was puzzling. How can a fight on day 4 (four 1 pt baddies) be so much harder than a fight on day 5 (one 5 pt baddie)? Positional play seemed mostly irrelevant. The final boss battle was a huge letdown. It either was going to be impossible or a cake walk. I happen to roll a Poison 3 and a Bone Saw 3, so I won effortlessly on Turn 3. I would have been clobbered if I had rolled just a few points worse.

A few words regarding component quality: I am not sure why folks praise these so much. Sure, compared to cardboard this approach to physically producing a game is a novelty, but if you have ever seen really great poker chips and plastic cards all this is just infuriating. As someone who knows quality poker chips (I own a set of Paulsons) the chips here are just crappy, slugged PVC chips. Again, OK compared to Walmart quality, but extraordinary? The cards are even worse. Lots of card players handling plastic cards all the time (e.g., playing Poker) would run away from these slippery PVC nightmares as fast as possible. Compared to really nice acetate cards (by Modiano, KEM, or Fournier) this is laughable quality.
Bottom line: I'd rather have top shelf wood and cardboard components than bottom feeder chips and plastic cards. Not to mention that the printing is dull and difficult to read (but, hey, cards are plastic).

Premessa: Non è male come gioco. Il progetto di base è bello, la qualità dei materiali é molto alta.
Veniamo al dunque:
- Prima di tutto il regolamento é confusionario, fatto malissimo e non parlo di traduzioni. Intendo proprio come organizzazione. Devi saltare da una parte all’altra. C’è poca chiarezza e devi consultare di continuo la scheda personaggio, il regolamento, le azioni e le abilità nemiche. Abilità che se va male rendono ancora più noiosa la partita: alcuni nemici possono subire un danno per turno. Devi quindi essere fortunato con i dadi altrimenti perderai 15 minuti per una battaglia banale.
- la difficoltà: ma vi sembra normale che debbano “facilitare” il gioco perché altrimenti rischi di morire subito poiché il personaggio é scarso di base rispetto ai nemici? Devi quasi “imbrogliare” avendo almeno +2 vite a cui aggiungi altri potenziamenti altrimenti vieni sconfitto come un fesso.
- I personaggi sono appena 4. Tutti gli altri vanno acquistati da parte. Le “espansioni” sono standalon. e costano quanto il gioco base. Ottime le chip, I tappetini e le carte. Ripeto: Alta qualità. Queste sono le cose che “giustificano” il prezzo.
- Il gioco é troppo ripetitivo. E una volta che hai capito cosa potenziare e come giocare diventa banale. La tua sfortuna può riguardare solo la chip del nemico che peschi per l’evento in base al numero dei giorni. I nemici sono banali, troppi banali. Tutti tranne i boss che hanno un dado speciale .
- La “rigiocabilitá” : Non è che ci siano differenze negli eventi..o combatti o lanci i dadi. Stop. In solo sono pochi, ho così aggiunto gli “eventi generici” ed è stato un po’ “diverso”. Non capisco perché devo usare le carte “solo” se anche negli “eventi generici” c’è scritto “per 1-2 giocatori”.

Conclusione:
Non si può fare un gioco di 150€ giustificando tutto con i materiali. Bastava una plancia di cartone in cui inserire i dadi. Tokens di cartone per i nemici o in porta monete. Stessa funzionalità ma un costo molto più basso.
Ne ho sentito parlare così tanto bene che sono rimasto allibito.
Mi ha annoiato eppure ho provato a giocare in vari modi per una settimana ma il gioco questo é. Se poi ti capitano alcuni nemici ti annoi e le prendi.
Gioco sufficiente che poteva essere più leggero di peso ed economico.

2025 update. My desire to play this has diminished significantly with the release of BOTSE, which has introduced most of the elements I feel were missing in TMB.

I held off on rating this for a while, but the number of interactions in the game and truly awful rulebook just make this such a pain to play. I rarely have a game where I am confident I didn't make multiple mistakes, but there are just too many things to look up.

Furthermore, for all the content that is included, you will probably only use half of it. Most of the skills are so unhelpful that it is better to just use skills points to add basic stats to your character. It's one of my most played games, probably close to 30 plays and I still haven't used some skills and don't anticipate ever doing so. The adventures are too tight to waste even a single skill point.

The monster progression is weird and unintuitive. Worst of all though, is the monster difficulty rule. Making the difficulty based on the day has ruined so many scenarios for me. If I didn't have the skill to succeed in one battle, why would the game expect it to succeed with the exact same skill set in a harder battle? Maybe make the difficulty based on progress, not day. I've learned to pack up the game if you fail two scnarios. It will just snowball from there.

All that said, the game is undeniably fun. Something about picking skills to roll and chucking a bumch of unique dice is such a blast. But there's a lot that gets in the way of the fun factor here.
Need to play this more to see if this score is final. I don't quite see what all the hype is about. But we'll see.

6.5/10: Too many bones is an insanely overproduced cooperative adventure game where you try to go into a scenario, gain skills and power up to take on a boss. You fight enemies on a grid map using dice that you can unlock and add more to your pool.

The quality of components here is astoundingly good (chip theory) but the usability of some of those things (day tracker, enemies) is not where I would want it to be. Enemies' info is very small and can be hard to read quickly and often require me(someone with perfect vision) to pick up the enemy to read it. The combat map is very small and positioning yourself is not much of the game and I left wishing there was more to do in each map. Because the map is always the same, battles didn't feel that unique.

Each character is unique with very large play aids that differentiate each of them. They all have their own unique pool of dice to build from which allows you to try different things each time you play. This is fun albeit restrictive in many ways. The level of customization is not insanely high like in The Elder Scrolls: Betrayal of the Second Era.

The missions and story are simple, but interesting and the game is quite hard if not played at the easiest difficulty. I don't mind hard games, especially not coop games, but Too Many Bones can really suffer if you fail at missions. Each one you fail leaves you further and further behind where you need to be to win and can really snowball you in an unfun way. Rolling your awesome custom dice is super fun, but you don't get to do it that much and I was left wishing I could have had more chances to roll than I had. Combat is quite quick, especially if it goes well for you, and often if it goes very badly it can also play fast.

I have to mention the Keywords. There are simply WAY too many keywords and it results in the beginning and during battles looking like this;
'New enemy comes out'
"Oh, it has Thick skin... what does that do." some reading later " oh and it has Mischief what's that do?" followed by more reading.

I find this super clunky and there are so many keywords I can't see myself memorizing them and breaking out of this clunky flow.

In general, I had fun playing and will play more, but I am not rushing to play more. There is enough that I have gripes with here and I just don't see gameplay becoming smooth without 25+ plays and I just don't know that I like this game enough to invest that time with it.

This will be a bit of an oddball review since I am unsure how to approach this. I have only ever played this game twice. I was a huge fan of the game after my first play. The system is incredible with so much potential to expand the game in different directions - something that TMB has done very successfully. TMB is an exceptional game that gives me a lot of what I look for in a game.

This was before I had played Elder Scrolls: BotSE though. My second play of TMB was after 25+ games of BotSE and I found myself missing some of the enhancements that BotSE has made to the system. So it is hard for me to judge this game, because after all, there would be no BotSE without TMB.

To be more specific, I do love the custom characters that TMB comes with. It gives them personality - something you won't get with the characters you build in BotSE. Plus, each character seems to have at least 2 distinct build paths you can take, making them feel different with every play. TMB is a lifestyle game. As is BotSE though. Other than the individual personalities for characters, I think BotSE does everything better than TMB. The character building is a lot more interesting with near infinite build paths. I also felt the tenacity system is better than the bones system in multiple ways: it doesn't lock your dice, the abilities are more powerful/relevant, and there are more ways to get tenacity than just rolling misses. TMBs skill dice also feel less relevant since they are one time use per battle. So most of the time you are just rolling your standard attack/defend dice, making the skill dice feel less important. BotSE with its cooldown track is a much better system. Then there is the whole overworld system, which allows you to choose the type of encounter you want as opposed to being locked into one.

All in all, I will never turn down a game of TMB, but sadly with BotSE around, I don't find myself looking for a lot of reasons to seek out TMB.

Why not a 10?
It is a case of the game having enough replayability but not infinite replayability. While many of my favorite gaming moments have come from this game, it is due to particular cards that either you experience once and the novelty wears off. These moments will get rarer over extra plays. Another reason is that before mastering the game it is a fun puzzle, but once you do it one needs a curated pool of baddies and combat boils down to a particular order of upgrading stats and a few skills. The game thus loses its replayability. The baddie and card systems are good, but stat vs skill and skill vs skill balance is bad (the game balance throws you vertically scaling challenges with increasing raw stats, giving more importance to rolling more dice each turn vs one time use skills or skills that offer lateral value, and the skills themselves are not balanced with each other, leading to just one optimal build). Also losing vs winning a combat makes a huge impact, leading the game to be played more of as a roguelike survival experience. But then the playtime varies wildly, from 30 minutes to 4 hours. Another problem is the tyrants. None feel epic. They could take some inspiration from KDM. Some extra health could at last make the battle feel more epic, but the newer ones starting from S&D are just frustrating to defeat, not epic.

Why I love it?
-Quirky theme, creative events, character growth, rich tactical combat and boss battles.
-The solid, toy-like components are a joy to move around and engaging.
-The simple turn structure flows well.
-It doesn't need inserts nor sleeves, so you waste 0 on 3rd party accessories.
-Replayability given by the gearloc combinations, their builds at a specific point in time and the random baddies all form unique puzzles each time.

Some of its limitations:
-You can't opt out of expensive premium components. Ironically, the component out of all that needed the most to be premium was the Premium Health Chips, which are an add-on (due to the standard ones being slippery).
-Unbalanced: stats are way better than most skills, limiting builds. Many baddies are unbalanced and so are encounter rewards (training rewards are much better, maybe except for some unique rewards).
-Inconsistent experience: some games will be so so or even bad, with an amazing game here and there.
-Downtime reading the reference sheets, rules or seeking answers online. Learning a gearloc is like learning a small to medium game in a single sheet, where sometimes 2 full sized ones were necessary. This is another case of being stingy precisely where one didn't need to be stingy.
-Tyrants are a weak point: pre-Splice&Dice tyrants are underwhelming (except for Goblin King and Gendricks). S&D tyrants are frustrating to defeat.
-If you play enough, it becomes too easy. See variants for how to increase difficulty.

Player Scaling:
The game works best with 2-3 gearlocs. 1 is very swingy, and 4 tends to be a spiral of easy. The board also fits 2-3 gearlocs better.

Starter Kit:
Undertow is an excellent starter packed with a ton of value, and is one of the most expandable standalones. Premium chips are a must. Core Set and additional gearlocs are also very good.
*Expensive entry point: Undertow, Core Set, Premium Chips, Rage of Tyranny, Gasket/Ghillie/Dart, 40 Days in Daelore, Splice&Dice.
Unbreakable is a good entry point if one wants to limit the buy in price of the game, which can get ridiculously high otherwise. I would go:
*Cheap entry point: Unbreakable, Premium Chips, 40 Caves in Daelore, Gasket/Ghillie/Dart.

-Bullet is a lighter, cheaper alternative with a puzzly grid and hero/boss match up asymmetry.

Build-A-Tyrant modification:
-Instead of drawing 2 1pt and 2 5pt from S&D, draw a random 5pt from the baddie pool, and assign as normal initiative, health, attack, defense. But also assign the tyrant dice equal to the baddie's type(s) and also put that baddie into the BAT skills. This is normal difficulty. For higher ones, you can try repeating this with a 5pt again or instead draw a 20pt.
-Extra Splicing: Center hole of lab mat is labeled 0. In this space goes the first defeated baddie, the next onto 1, then 2, ... up to 4, which holds up to 5 baddies maximum. When resolving the Splice at end of battle, the center baddie always counts for all splices as the 3rd baddie.
-BAT cap. If BAT attempts to increase a track/stat/slot where it already has the maximum, instead increase another track/stat/slot.
-Streamlined Splicing: No longer use a bag with 10 splice dice. Use 4 dice only and roll. Wherever the dice land, pick them up in English reading order (top most and if 2 are tied, leftmost). The 4 dice to be used are as follows:
-Tyrant/Tyrant/Targets/Targets/ExtraBaddies/ExtraBaddies
-Attack/Attack/Targets/Targets/ExtraBaddies/Ranged
-Skill/Skill/Ranged/Ranged/Targets/ExtraBaddies
-Attack/Attack/Defense/Defense/Health/Health
Higher difficulty variant:
-Lose when all your gearlocs get KO'd in a battle.
-Remove all weak baddies, use all baddie types regardless of tyrant.
-Signal: always calls a 5pt baddie (except in the initial days).
-Raiding: also counts the baddie itself.
-One Mind: counts every other baddie, not only beasts (may be overturned, the other option is to also activate itself, One Mind can only be activated once per turn. This means, regardless of how many One Mind's there are, if every beast does not get KO'd and gearlocs don't lose before, every beast would attack twice).
-Double tyrants: Fight against 2 tyrants at the same time!
-Gendricks: is hardier (can only take 1 damage per round).
-Overclocked Nobulous: roll both dice 3 times instead of once.
-Build a Tyrant: Center space is space 0. Place first defeated baddie here, and it counts as adjacent for all 4 dice. Do the initial splice with all baddies (not only from S&D). From the initial splice, also select one 5pt baddie to place in the BAT skills area and one type among all to add as tyrant die.
Tantrum re-balance: Have Tantrum always have its lowest available rage die in its active slot, and always advance to the next available die. This means you can use rage 2 > 1 > 3 or 3 > 2 > 1, or not get as badly screwed with mischief. Axe Collector BP to give 2 axes instead of 3 (alternatively, make each axe deal only 1 damage). As it stands, Tantrum can deal massive damage and tank/heal himself forever with just a defense investment, too strong. And rage is just too fragile, particularly with mischief around.
